Description: Small mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply modelled with incised single lines, representing the features of clypeus, prothorax and elytra, with humeral callosities present and feathered legs at front; profile compact; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines roughly forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside decorated with representation of a lion walking to right and turning head to look backwards, with an arrow-shaped element in front of animal; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; thick pale greenish turquoise glaze; yellowish cream core; glaze of back quite eroded.
Curator's comments: Scarabs with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, Pl. 37, 34-45). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A73-88, see especially A73 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 40)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 95, Type XXVIII A73)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.014) (phase 3)
